Clarifying the ninety-two matters of single offenses, part six. The Buddha was staying at ÅšrÄvastÄ«, as explained above.
At that time, the Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
Because the TathÄgata eats only one meal a day, his body feels light and he abides in comfort.
You should also eat only one meal a day. Because of eating only one meal a day, your body will feel light and you will abide in comfort.
At that time, Venerable Vá¹›ji said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!

The Buddha told Vá¹›ji:

If you are unable to eat only one meal a day, then get up in the morning, take two alms bowls into the village to beg for food, and use one bowl for breakfast and one bowl for lunch. This is still two meals.
In this way, he was taught a second and third time, but still said he was unable to do it.
At that time, all the disciples accepted the World-Honored One's teaching, except for Bhadra.

Furthermore, the Buddha was staying in Shravasti. At that time, the bhikshus begged for food at improper times, and were criticized by the worldly people:
How can the shamans, the disciples of the Buddha, beg for food at improper times?
They have forgotten the fruits of the path, what path is there?
The bhikshus heard this and went to inform the World-Honored One of the reason.
The Buddha told the bhikshus:
You renunciants begging for food at improper times, you should indeed be criticized by the worldly people.
From today onwards, I do not allow begging for food at improper times.
Herein, it should be explained in detail as in the Udayin Sutra.
Furthermore, the Buddha was staying in Shravasti, as explained above.
At that time, the bhikshus ate in the evening, and were criticized by the worldly people:
How can the Åšramaá¹‡as, sons of ÅšÄkya, eat at night?

These people have lost the Dharma of Åšramaá¹‡as, what path do they have?
The bhiká¹£us heard this and took this cause and condition to inform the World-Honored One.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:

Furthermore, the Buddha stayed at ÅšrÄvastÄ«, the details of which are explained above.

At that time, the bhiká¹£us entered the village to beg for food before the meal, and after the meal, they went to various gardens, ponds, and places where people gathered to play to beg for food. They were criticized by the people of the world:
You all, look at these Åšramaá¹‡as, sons of ÅšÄkya, who beg in our homes.

The bhiká¹£us heard this and took this cause and condition to inform the World-Honored One. The Buddha said:
Call this bhiká¹£u.
Having called him, the Buddha asked about the above matter:
Is it true?
He replied:
It is true.
World-Honored One!
The Buddha asked the bhiká¹£u:
What did you use the alms you received in the morning for?
He replied:
For the meal.
He asked again:
What did you use the alms you received after the meal for?
He replied:
To prepare for tomorrow's meal.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£u:
How can you keep leftover food and eat it?
From today onward, I do not allow eating at improper times and eating leftover food.
Furthermore, the Buddha stayed at RÄjagá¹›ha, as explained in detail above.
At that time, because Venerable Bhadra had a sense of shame and remorse, when entering the village, it was like entering a military camp.
At that time, he took two alms bowls and entered the village to beg for food. After obtaining [food], he used one bowl for today's meal and one bowl for tomorrow's meal.
At that time, the bhiká¹£us wanted to enter the village to beg for food, and they called to Bhadrika, saying:
Elder!
Let us go together to enter the village to beg for food.
He replied:
You go by yourselves, I cannot go.
The bhiká¹£us said:
Elder!
You have gained great benefits, you can eat one meal and be at ease for two days.
He replied:
I do not eat one meal and be at ease for two days. Because when I enter the village, it is like entering an army formation, so I take two alms bowls and beg for food for two days.
When the bhiká¹£us heard this, they went to inform the World-Honored One of the circumstances. The Buddha said:
Call Bhadrika to come.
After he was called to come, the Buddha asked Bhadrika:
Is it really so?
He replied:ğŸ”½Yes, it is so.
It is true.
The Buddha said:
Although you want to save on many conditions, from today onwards you are not allowed to eat at improper times or to keep food overnight.
As explained in detail in the Sutra of Bhadra's Thread.
Furthermore, the Buddha was staying in Shravasti, as explained in detail above.
At that time, Aniruddha was drying rotten barley gruel on a black rock on the side of the mountain of sages. The Buddha then went there with his spiritual powers, knowing but deliberately asking:
What are you doing?
He replied:
World-Honored One!
The disciples with faith and joy want to rely on it tomorrow, so they do not enter the village to beg for food.
The Buddha said:
Although you want to save on many conditions, from today onwards you are not allowed to eat at improper times or to keep food overnight.
The Buddha returned to Shravasti with his spiritual powers.
The Buddha told the bhikshus:

All those who rely on ÅšrÄvastÄ« should gather together. For ten benefits, I establish precepts for the bhiká¹£us. Those who have already heard should listen again.ğŸ”½If a bhiká¹£u eats at the wrong time, he commits a pÄyattika offense.
If a bhiká¹£u eats leftover food, he commits a pÄyattika offense.
Bhiká¹£u is as explained above.
Wrong time means after the time has passed, like the blink of an eye or a blade of grass. Passing this is called the wrong time.
Food means flour, rice, wheat, fish, and meat.
If one eats mixed food, it is a pÄyattika offense.
PÄyattika is as explained above.
Bhiká¹£u is as explained above.
Leftover food means passing the time for a short while.
Short while means twenty moments is called an instant, twenty instants is called a finger snap, twenty finger snaps is called a roya, and twenty royas is called a short while.

When the day is at its longest, there are eighteen periods of time, when the night is at its shortest, there are twelve periods of time, when the night is at its longest, there are eighteen periods of time, when the day is at its shortest, there are twelve periods of time.
Food refers to the five proper foods and the five mixed proper foods. If one stops eating any of them, it is a pÄyattika offense.
PÄyattika means as explained above.
Time, non-time, intentional, unintentional, little, much, quickly, slowly, snow, ice.
Time means if one receives food at the proper time and eats it at the proper time, there is no offense.
If one passes the time of a hair's blink or a blade of grass, and eats after that time, it is one pÄyattika offense.
If one stops and eats after a period of time, one commits two pÄyattika offenses, committing the offense of eating at the wrong time and the offense of eating stopped food.
Non-time means if one receives food at the wrong time and eats it at the wrong time, one commits one pÄyattika offense.
If one stops for a while and then eats, one commits two offenses entailing expiation: eating at the wrong time and storing food and then eating.
Thus, intentionally receiving, unintentionally receiving, receiving much, receiving little, receiving quickly, receiving slowly - there are various distinctions like this.
As for receiving snow, if a bhiká¹£u wants to eat snow, he should receive it from a pure person.
If there is no pure person, he should wash his hands to make them pure and take it himself to eat. Hail is also like this. This is called ice and snow.

When a bhiká¹£u gets up in the morning, he should wash his hands to make them pure. He cannot just roughly wash the tips of the five fingers, nor can he wash up to the armpits. He should wash up to the wrist to make them pure. He cannot roughly wash, nor can he scrub until blood comes out. He should use the powder of jujube leaves or ash to wash his hands to make them pure and scrub until it makes a sound.
After washing his hands to make them pure, if he rubs them together again, they are then called impure and he should wash them again.
If the bowl has been washed and is still wet, it should be rubbed again. It is then considered clean and can be put away to dry.
Before a meal, a monk should protect his clean hands. If he touches his head, his lower robe, sandals, or a leather bag containing ghee or oil, he should wash his hands again as before.
If he touches his outer robe or upper robe, he should wash his hands again with water.
When a monk wishes to go out to beg for food, he should wash his hands clean and put on his robe for entering the village.
After putting on his robe for entering the village, he should wash his hands again, take his bowl, and enter the village.

If it is winter and cold, he may put his bowl in a bag. When he reaches the edge of the village, by a pond or flowing water, he should wash his hands clean.ğŸ”½If there is no water, he should enter the village and go to the dwelling place of the monks to ask for water to wash his hands.

If there is still none, go to the house of a faithful upÄsaka and seek clean water.
If there is still none, open the alms bowl bag, take out the bowl, beg for food in one place, and return after obtaining food.

If using grass leaves, after washing, remove the rice touched by the fingers from the bowl, pour the rice onto the stone or grass leaves. When pouring the rice, do not pour it into an impure place with the hand.

If there is no pure person, where birds have eaten, one should scrape away the pure part and take it oneself.

At that time, a householder gave birth to a daughter who was unparalleled in beauty. Her parents were delighted.

Someone answered:
The daughter of a certain householder.
The king's physiognomist thought:
The features of this woman are suitable to be the king's chief consort.
The physiognomist then said to the king:

She replied:
Her name is Blind Eye.

The king said:
This name is inauspicious and not what I need.

Venerable One, do you need pastries?ğŸ”½He replied:

Elder!

He replied:
From the house of the blind woman.
When the bhiká¹£us heard this, they went to her house again and obtained the same as before.
In this way, they went one by one to beg, and all the gifts for the woman were exhausted.
In this way, on the second and third days, the husband again sent someone to call, and again said:
Wait a little longer.
The bhiká¹£us went to beg every day and it was all exhausted. Because the wife did not return in time, her husband became very angry and said:
I now sent a message to call her, but she only said the gifts were not ready and did not come. She must have a mind for someone else.
He then sent her away and sought another woman.
When the blind mother heard that her daughter had been sent away, she wept bitterly.
The daughter also sat there sadly, thinking that her mother had not sent her in time, so she was sent away.
The people in the neighboring houses asked:

They then fully answered with the above matter.
The neighbors blamed them, saying:
Why didn't you send your daughter first and then prepare other food to offer to the bhiká¹£us?
The bhiká¹£us heard this and went to inform the World-Honored One of the matter. The Buddha said:

When they arrived, the Buddha asked the bhiká¹£us:

They replied:

Furthermore, the Buddha was staying in RÄjagá¹›ha, as explained in detail above.

At that time, there was a merchant leader in the city named Abhaya who, together with other merchants, was about to go on a long journey. The merchant's wife was preparing various provisions for the journey at home.

Seeing them, the merchant's wife was filled with faith and joy, and asked:

He replied:

In this way, on the second and third days, they prepared provisions, and the monks came to beg, until on the fourth day, they finished preparing the provisions and set out, but they could not catch up with their companions and were robbed by bandits, losing all their belongings.
When the merchant's wife heard this, she was distressed and wept. The neighbors asked:
Why are you like this?
She then explained the matter in detail to the neighbors.
The neighbors said:
Why didn't you prepare provisions and send the travelers on their way first, and then make offerings to the monks?
When the monks heard this, they told the World-Honored One in detail. The Buddha said:
Call those monks here.
When they arrived, the Buddha asked the monks:
Is it really so?
They replied:
It is true.
The Buddha said:
This is a bad thing. The giver does not know the proper amount, but the receiver should know the proper amount.
This is not the Dharma, not the Vinaya, not the Buddha's teachings, and cannot be used to cultivate wholesome dharmas.

The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
All those who rely on RÄjagá¹›ha to live should gather together. For ten reasons, I establish precepts for the bhiká¹£us. Those who have already heard should listen again.
If a bhiká¹£u goes to a layperson's house and is freely given cakes and pastries, he may accept two or three bowls and go outside to share them with sick bhiká¹£us.

If one is given food by a nun, one may receive three bowls and take it outside to share with sick monks.
If a monk thinks:
Who can do many things?
He may say to the nun:

Then fill another bowl in another container, and receive one bowl himself, and say to the woman:
If any monks come, give them this bowl.
If more come, give them this second bowl.
Later, if more come, do not give them any more.
If you give, you will have little merit.
After the monk takes the food out, if he meets other monks on the way, he should say:
There is food at such-and-such a house. You should take your share.
The second monk should also do the same.
It is not a nun's cake, nor is it provisions for the road. It is not for monks to send provisions, nor is it given by one's own discretion.
Not for a girl's cake means not like sending a blind girl.
Not for provisions on the road means not like the fearless merchants and so forth.
For a monk means to do it for a monk, not for others.
Not for sending provisions means that if one does it for others except for these two cases, one may take it without offense.

If one is not given freely, one may take it as one wishes. If the blind girl leaves and the stepmother gives it later, one may take it without offense.ğŸ”½If the girl has already gone to her husband's house and gives it, one may take it without offense.
If the merchant has already left and the merchant's wife gives it later, one may take it without offense.
If the merchant has already arrived at his destination and gives it, one may take it without offense.
If on the day of a household's wedding or feast, a monk goes to their house, the host may say:
Venerable!
I wanted to send a message to invite you, but I was afraid it would not be possible, let alone you coming yourself.
In this way, one may take freely without offense.
Therefore it is said.

At that time, the group of six monks went to a ghee house to beg for ghee, to an oil house to beg for oil, to a milk house to beg for milk, to a curd house to beg for curd, to a honey house to beg for honey, to a molasses house to beg for molasses, to a fish house to beg for fish, and to a meat house to beg for meat. They were ridiculed by worldly people, who said:

Yet now these Åšramaá¹‡as cannot beg for coarse food, but go to a ghee house to beg for ghee, and even to a meat house to beg for meat.
What principles do these corrupt people have?
The monks went to inform the World-Honored One of this cause and condition. The Buddha said:
Call the group of six monks.
After they arrived, the Buddha asked the group of six monks:
Is it true that you did such a thing?
They replied:ğŸ”½Yes, it is true.
It is true.
The Buddha said to the group of six monks:
This is a bad thing.
Haven't you always heard me, using countless skillful means, praising few desires and criticizing excessive desires?
This is not the Dharma, not the Vinaya, not the teachings of the Buddha, and cannot be used to cultivate wholesome dharmas.
From today onward, begging for delicious food is not allowed.
Furthermore, the Buddha was staying in the Nyagrodha Monastery of the Sakyas in Kapilavastu. For the sake of the five benefits, he inspected the monks' quarters every five days and saw a sick monk.
The Buddha knew but deliberately asked:
How is your illness?
Is it getting worse?
He replied:
It's not getting worse.
The Buddha said:
Can't you ask for food and medicine according to your illness?
He replied:
I can beg, but the World-Honored One has prohibited begging for delicious food, so I dare not beg.
I have no patrons and no one to give me.
The Buddha said:
From today onwards, sick monks are allowed to beg for fine food.
The Buddha told the monks:
All those who rely on Kapilavastu should gather. For ten reasons, I establish precepts for the monks. Those who have already heard should listen again.
If there are such fine foods as ghee, oil, honey, molasses, milk, curd, fish, and meat in the homes of the faithful, if a sick monk begs for such fine foods for himself, it is a pÄyattika offense.
Home is as explained above.
Ghee, oil, honey, molasses, milk, curd, fish, and meat are as explained above in the second precept on stealing. Such are called fine foods.
Sick means the World-Honored One says there is no offense.
Illness refers to jaundice, carbuncles, hemorrhoids, incontinence, jaundice, malaria, coughing, tuberculosis, wind and swelling, water and swelling, and various other such illnesses.
For one's own sake means to request for oneself or to have someone request. If one eats, it is a pÄyattika offense.
PÄyattika means as explained above.
If a bhiká¹£u has a fever, the doctor says:
This illness should take ghee.
One may beg for ghee, but one should not go to a non-believer's house to request.
Why is it so?
When requesting, it slanders the bhiká¹£us, saying they only request ghee for the sake of delicious flavors.
One should not go to request from those who slander the bhiká¹£us' long and short [comings].
One should go to a faithful upÄsaka's house to request. When obtaining, one should calculate for oneself.
If a bhiká¹£u has a wind illness, the doctor says:
One should take oil.
At that time, if one obtains oil for begging, one should not beg from an oil presser's house, nor should one go to an unbelieving person's house, as explained in the ghee section.
If a bhiká¹£u has a water disease, the doctor says:
This should take honey.
At that time, if one obtains honey for begging, one should not beg from a honey collector's house, nor should one go to an unbelieving person's house to beg, as explained in the ghee section.
If a bhiká¹£u has a dry and emaciated disease, the doctor says:
This should take rock candy.
One should not go to a sugarcane presser's house to ask, nor should one go to an unbelieving person's house to ask, as explained in the ghee section.
If a bhiká¹£u has a cold, the doctor says:
One should take rock candy and curd in combination.
One should not go to an unbelieving person's house to ask, as explained in the ghee section.
If a bhiká¹£u has a lower disease, the doctor says:
This should take milk.
At that time, one may beg for milk from a cowherd, and when obtaining it, one should consider how much to take.
If a bhiká¹£u wants to induce vomiting or purgation, the doctor says:
First take fish juice.
At that time, one may beg for fish juice, but one may not beg from a fishmonger, nor may one beg from an unbelieving household, as explained above.
If a bhiká¹£u wants to bleed by pricking the head, or if he takes a purgative, the doctor says:
This should be taken with meat juice.
At that time, one may beg for meat juice, but one may not beg from a butcher or an unbelieving household, as explained above.
If a bhiká¹£u goes begging for food to the side of a person measuring ghee, the person measuring ghee says:
Venerable!
What do you seek?
He replies:
I want to beg for food.
He says:
There is no food, only this ghee. If you need it, I will give it.
If a bhiká¹£u needs it at that time, he may receive a full bowl without offense.
If he has a companion, he may encourage him to give without offense.
The same applies to oil, honey, molasses, milk, and curds.
If a bhiká¹£u receives almsfood and his bowl is filled with porridge and gruel, and there is nothing to be obtained in the begging bowl, he may request a drink.
If the layperson says:
There is no drink, only meat broth, if you need it, I will give it to you.
At that time, he may take it.
If he further asks:
There is also meat, if you need it, I will give it to you.
At that time, he may take it to fill the vessel without offense.
He may also go to a sugarcane press and request sugarcane juice. If they say:
We don't have sugarcane juice, only molasses, if you need it, I will give it to you.
The bhiká¹£u, if he needs it, may take it to fill the bowl without offense, and he may also encourage them to give to his companion.
He may also go to an oil press and beg for oil dregs. If the host says:
We don't have oil dregs, if you need oil, I will give it to you.
If he needs it, he may take it to fill the bowl without offense, and he may also encourage them to give to his companion.
If one obtains whey and says:
I have no whey, I only have milk curd, if you need it, I will give it to you.
If the bhiká¹£u needs it, he may take a full bowl without offense, and he may also encourage his companions to take it.
One may beg for sugarcane, and may beg for fine food for visiting bhiká¹£us and bhiká¹£us traveling long distances. If one is traveling on one's own, one may also beg.
If a bhiká¹£u begs and obtains the eight kinds of fine food in one place, and eats them separately, he commits many pÄyattika offenses.
